key_points: The Trump administration has proposed a 28-point peace plan for Ukraine that requires Kyiv to cede territory, including parts of Donetsk and Luhansk, and recognize Crimea and other occupied regions as de facto Russian territory.
The plan includes a limit on Ukraine’s military size to 600,000 personnel and a commitment that Ukraine will not join NATO or allow NATO troops there.
The United States would recognize Russian control over Crimea, Luhansk, and Donetsk, marking a reversal of longstanding U.S. policy supporting Ukrainian territorial integrity.

members.title: Ukrainian President Faces Stark Choice Over U.S. Peace Plan Seen as Favoring Russia
key_points: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warns that Ukraine faces a pivotal choice between upholding its sovereignty and risking the loss of vital American support.
The U.S. peace proposal, favored by Russian President Vladimir Putin, includes significant territorial concessions to Russia and restrictions on Ukraine’s military and NATO aspirations.
Putin has welcomed the plan as potentially forming the basis of a final peace settlement, claiming it reflects longstanding Kremlin demands.

members.title: Putin Says U.S. Plan for Ukraine Could Form the Basis for a Final Peace Settlement
key_points: Russian President Vladimir Putin welcomes a U.S. peace proposal as a potential basis for a final settlement, though he criticizes it for lacking substantive discussion and for not including Ukrainian consent.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy expresses concern over the U.S. proposal, which includes territorial concessions, reduced military size, and blocked NATO membership, and warns of a difficult choice between sovereignty and American support.

The U.S. plan, described as a 'modernized' version, contains many of Putin's demands and offers limited security guarantees, raising concerns among European allies about its fairness and long-term implications.

canonical_title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration’s claims linking Tylenol and autism

members.title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration’s claims linking Tylenol and autism
key_points: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has partially walked back his earlier claim that Tylenol use during pregnancy directly causes autism, stating that while a link is 'very suggestive,' it is not sufficient to conclude causation.

The World Health Organization and reputable health agencies have consistently found no consistent association between Tylenol and autism, emphasizing the need for medical consultation rather than fear-based recommendations.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed a lawsuit against Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, alleging deceptive marketing of Tylenol as the only safe painkiller for pregnant women, citing claims made by Trump and Kennedy.

canonical_title: Are astronomers wrong about dark energy? New study casts doubt on universe’s accelerating expansion
entities: Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST)

members.title: Are astronomers wrong about dark energy? New study casts doubt on universe’s accelerating expansion
key_points: The universe's expansion might not be accelerating but could be slowing down, challenging the long-standing belief in dark energy's constant strength.
A new study suggests that Type Ia supernovae's brightness depends on the age of their progenitor stars, introducing a previously unaccounted bias in cosmological measurements.

This age-dependent brightness relation could mean that dark energy is not constant and may be evolving over time, potentially altering the future fate of the universe from infinite expansion to a possible 'Big Crunch'.

canonical_title: In One Week, Trump Moves to Reshape U.S. Environmental Policy

members.title: In One Week, Trump Moves to Reshape U.S. Environmental Policy
key_points: The Trump administration proposed a sweeping series of environmental rollbacks in one week, affecting wetlands, endangered species protections, and offshore oil and gas drilling across U.S. coastal waters.
The proposed changes to the Clean Water Act could strip federal protections from up to 55 million acres of wetlands, or about 85% of all wetlands nationwide.
Revisions to the Endangered Species Act would allow economic factors—like lost revenue from oil drilling—to influence species listing decisions, undermining science-based protections.

canonical_title: College 'sticker prices' have risen dramatically. Here's why

members.title: College 'sticker prices' have risen dramatically. Here's why
key_points: Over the past 30 years, average tuition for public and private four-year colleges has doubled after adjusting for inflation.
Harvard's tuition has increased from $2,400 in 1970 (adjusted to $21,000 today) to over $59,000 for the next academic year, with total cost including housing and food reaching more than $86,000.
The 'sticker price' is not what most families pay; the 'net price' — after financial aid — is still rising, though trends have stabilized or declined in recent years.

digest_abridged:
College tuition has doubled over 30 years, with Harvard's cost rising from $21k to over $59k, and net prices still increasing despite stabilization in financial aid trends.

key_points: Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic has denied allegations that he participated in 'sniper tourism' during the 1990s siege of Sarajevo, calling the claims a 'lie' and 'malicious disinformation'.

The allegations stem from a Croatian journalist's complaint to Italian prosecutors, citing a 2022 Slovenian documentary, 'Sarajevo Safari', which claims wealthy foreigners paid to shoot at civilians in Sarajevo.
Vucic claims he never held a sniper rifle, never killed or wounded anyone, and was not involved in any combat activities during the siege, having instead worked as a journalist in Pale.

canonical_title: Are there lessons for the U.S. in this European country's struggle with measles?
entities: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

members.title: Are there lessons for the U.S. in this European country's struggle with measles?
key_points: Romania's measles outbreaks are not due to poverty or lack of resources, but to complex social, political, and historical factors, including post-Communist political transitions and vaccine hesitancy.
A decline in public trust in vaccines, initially triggered by the 2008 HPV campaign, led to a steady drop in measles vaccination coverage from above 95% to just 62% by 2023.
Even in wealthy, developed countries like Romania, measles can reemerge when immunization rates fall below 95%, proving that vaccine coverage is critical for disease prevention.

Romania's measles resurgence stems from vaccine hesitancy, not poverty, linked to post-Communist political shifts and past public trust erosion.

canonical_title: CDC Website Changed to Include False Claims Linking Autism and Vaccines

members.title: CDC Website Changed to Include False Claims Linking Autism and Vaccines
key_points: The CDC website updated in November 2025 to include claims that 'vaccines do not cause autism is not an evidence-based claim,' despite overwhelming scientific consensus showing no link between vaccines and autism.

The updated content includes a footnote stating the header 'Vaccines do not cause autism' remains due to a commitment by HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to Senator Bill Cassidy during his confirmation process.

The CDC page fails to cite key scientific studies—like the 2019 Danish study with 650,000 children—which found no link between vaccines and autism, and instead focuses on questionable or discredited research on aluminum and thimerosal.

canonical_title: Charlotte Officials Say Border Patrol Operation Has Ended, But DHS Insists Immigration Enforcement Will Continue

members.title: Charlotte Officials Say Border Patrol Operation Has Ended, But DHS Insists Immigration Enforcement Will Continue
key_points: Local officials in Charlotte, North Carolina, declared the federal immigration enforcement operation in the city as concluded on November 20, 2025, but the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) immediately disputed this, stating that 'Operation Charlotte’s Web' was not ending.

The operation, named 'Operation Charlotte’s Web,' led to over 370 arrests and caused significant community disruption, including over 30,000 students (about 20% of the district) missing school and numerous small businesses closing, such as a 28-year-old Colombian bakery.

Mecklenburg County Sheriff Garry McFadden and Charlotte Mayor Vi Lyles expressed relief and called for community unity and trust-building, while also emphasizing the need for clarity and accountability.

entities: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Vermont

members.title: Senior citizens will pay a lot more for Medicare in 2026
key_points: Medicare Part B premiums will increase by nearly 10% in 2026, reaching $202.90 per month, the largest increase in four years and the second-largest in history.
The premium rise will consume nearly one-third of the $56 Social Security cost-of-living adjustment received by retirees in 2026.
Medicare Advantage plans are shrinking in number, with a 10% reduction in offerings down to 3,373 plans, and some counties (e.g., Vermont) will have no Medicare Advantage options.

canonical_title: Do You Want Out of The Cult of Homeownership?

members.title: Do You Want Out of The Cult of Homeownership?
key_points: A 50-year mortgage is not a sustainable solution to housing affordability; it would increase total interest paid and extend the time to build home equity, potentially undermining wealth accumulation.
Homeownership remains culturally significant in America as a symbol of adulthood, stability, and commitment to a place, even as other markers like marriage or having children have become optional.

Co-buying homes with friends or relatives is gaining popularity, especially among younger generations, driven not just by affordability but by a desire to reduce loneliness and maintain social connection.

Auroras (northern lights) are visible across the U.S., Canada, and Europe, including major cities like Chicago, Seattle, Boston, and Atlanta.

members.title: US cancer registries, constrained by Trump policies, to recognize only ‘male’ or ‘female’ patients
key_points: Trump administration policies, including an executive order recognizing only male and female sexes, are forcing cancer registries to remove transgender and non-binary sex classifications from patient data.
This change will affect all federally funded cancer registries across the U.S., including those in 46 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and U.S. territories.
The federal CDC’s National Program of Cancer Registries and the NCI’s SEER program will only receive data where patients' sex is categorized as male, female, or unknown.

members.title: NTSB Releases Frame-by-Frame Images of Engine Separating During Deadly UPS Crash in Louisville

Frame-by-frame images show the engine separating, rising over the wing, and igniting a fireball—demonstrating a visible and dramatic failure sequence.
The left engine mount exhibited fatigue cracks and over-stressing in its 2 o’clock and 9 o’clock positions, suggesting long-term structural degradation.

canonical_title: What to Know About the Nearly 10% Climb in a Key Medicare Expense for 2026

members.title: What to Know About the Nearly 10% Climb in a Key Medicare Expense for 2026
key_points: The standard Medicare Part B premium increases to $202.90 per month in 2026, a 9.7% rise from the previous year and 66% higher than a decade ago.
The annual Part B deductible increases to $283, a 70.5% rise over the past ten years.

The Part B premium rise consumes a significant portion of the 2.8% Social Security COLA, reducing the effective COLA for most retirees to around 1.9% for average earners and 1% for lower-income beneficiaries.

entities: Franklin County Common Pleas Judge David Young

members.title: Officer Acquitted in Death of Ta’Kiya Young, a Pregnant Black Mother Accused of Shoplifting
key_points: Officer Connor Grubb was acquitted of all charges, including murder, in the death of 21-year-old Ta’Kiya Young, a pregnant Black mother accused of shoplifting.
Bodycam footage showed Ta’Kiya Young refusing to exit her car and turning her steering wheel, causing her vehicle to move forward and collide with Grubb, who fired one shot through the windshield.
The jury acquitted Grubb because the prosecution failed to prove he knew Young was pregnant when he shot her, leading Judge David Young to drop four of ten counts related to the unborn daughter.

members.title: Brazil Supreme Court Orders Preemptive Arrest of Former President Jair Bolsonaro
key_points: Jair Bolsonaro, former President of Brazil, was preemptively arrested by the Supreme Court on November 22, 2025, for violating his ankle monitor, which the court interpreted as an intent to flee.

The arrest was ordered by Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes, who cited a video by Flávio Bolsonaro (son) that allegedly incited street demonstrations to undermine judicial and democratic institutions.
Bolsonaro was previously under house arrest since August 2025, following conviction for leading a coup attempt in 2023 and for forming an armed criminal organization.

canonical_title: Fact vs. Fiction: The Real Story Behind the Murdaugh Murders and Hulu’s Dramatized Retelling

members.title: Fact vs. Fiction: The Real Story Behind the Murdaugh Murders and Hulu’s Dramatized Retelling
key_points: The Hulu series 'Murdaugh: Death in the Family' blends factual events with dramatized interpretations, emphasizing emotional storytelling over strict accuracy.

Gloria Satterfield, the Murdaugh housekeeper, died in 2018, but the show incorrectly portrays her as alive after the 2019 boat crash, and fabricates a scene of her tripping due to Alex Murdaugh’s pressure, with no evidence to support it.

The core of Alex Murdaugh’s financial fraud — diverting settlement money from clients into a fake 'Forge Consulting' account — is factual, though the show dramatizes the settlement amount from $2.765 million to $3.8 million and falsely implies he kept the money for himself.

digest_abridged:
Hulu's 'Murdaugh: Death in the Family' dramatizes real events, misrepresents Gloria Satterfield's death and financial fraud details, prioritizing emotional impact over factual precision.

key_points: The Supreme Court paused a federal lower court order that blocked Texas’ new congressional maps, citing urgency and proximity to the 2026 elections.
Texas claimed the redistricting was driven by partisan politics, not race, and argued that federal courts should not intervene due to the timing of the elections.

A U.S. District Judge, Jeffrey Brown, ruled that the Justice Department’s letter urging racial changes in districts constituted a violation of the 14th Amendment’s equal protection clause, calling it factually and legally flawed.

key_points: The Trump administration is proposing to open federal waters off the entire coastline of California to offshore oil drilling, a move that hasn't happened since the late 1960s.

The administration is also proposing new oil drilling in the Eastern Gulf of Mexico, approximately 100 nautical miles off Florida’s coast, a region previously banned from drilling during the first Trump administration.

California Governor Gavin Newsom has strongly opposed the plan, calling it 'idiotic' and vowing to use all legal tools to protect the state's coastline, especially noting the absence of drilling near Mar-a-Lago.

canonical_title: A surprisingly common liver disease affects millions in the US. What to know, according to a doctor
entities: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

members.title: A surprisingly common liver disease affects millions in the US. What to know, according to a doctor
key_points: Metabolic dysfunction–associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) is now the most common chronic liver disease globally, affecting 30% to 40% of adults worldwide and approximately 1 in 3 U.S. adults.
MASLD is linked to obesity and type 2 diabetes, with up to 70–80% of obese individuals and 60–70% of diabetic individuals affected.
Most people with MASLD have no symptoms, making early detection difficult and reliant on routine blood tests or imaging studies such as abdominal ultrasounds.

key_points: The COP30 climate talks in Brazil failed to reach a consensus on a clear plan to phase out fossil fuels such as oil, gas, and coal.

canonical_title: Speaker Johnson’s narrow majority gets a bit more breathing room after Sherrill’s resignation

members.title: Speaker Johnson’s narrow majority gets a bit more breathing room after Sherrill’s resignation
key_points: House Speaker Mike Johnson holds a narrow majority of 219 Republicans and 213 Democrats after Democratic Rep. Mikie Sherrill's resignation, providing slightly more breathing room than initially expected.

The partisan breakdown is the most divided in nearly 100 years, with the last such narrow majority occurring in the 1930s during the Great Depression, making current conditions historically significant.
Passing legislation requires a majority of present members; with 435 seats, the magic number is 218, but vacancies and absences reduce this to 216 or fewer, making bipartisan consensus essential.

members.title: Why has Canada lost its measles-free status – and could the US be next?
key_points: Canada lost its measles elimination status after a large, multi-jurisdictional outbreak that began in October 2024 and spread across all provinces and territories, resulting in 5,000 confirmed cases and two deaths.
The Americas region has lost its elimination status due to the Canadian outbreak, with over 95% of cases now reported in Canada, Mexico, and the United States.

Measles is highly infectious and spreads through air, with symptoms including fever, runny nose, sore eyes, and a characteristic rash. It can be fatal, especially in babies and immunocompromised individuals.

The law criminalizes the performance of abortions as a felony, with penalties of up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine for doctors, though patients are protected from prosecution.

Three justices ruled that the ban is unconstitutionally vague under the state constitution, while two maintained it is constitutional, falling short of the required four-justice majority to declare it unconstitutional.

digest_abridged:
North Dakota Supreme Court fails to overturn abortion ban due to insufficient majority.

- https://apnews.com → AP → State court upholds abortion ban

- threshold for constitutional ruling: Four-justice majority

members.title: Supreme Court Blocks Order That Found Texas Congressional Map Likely Racially Biased
key_points: The U.S. Supreme Court temporarily blocked a federal court ruling that found Texas' 2026 congressional redistricting plan likely racially biased.
The decision was made by Justice Samuel Alito, who handles emergency appeals from Texas, and will remain in effect for several days while the court evaluates whether to allow the new map to be used.
The redistricting plan was created by Texas's Republican-led legislature in summer 2025 to secure five additional Republican seats in the House of Representatives.

canonical_title: Polar Vortex Disruption on the Way: A Rare November Event Could Bring Cold to North America and Europe
timeframes: over the next two weeks..two weeks

members.title: Polar Vortex Disruption on the Way: A Rare November Event Could Bring Cold to North America and Europe
key_points: A sudden stratospheric warming event is causing the polar vortex to weaken and potentially reverse, leading to cold air spilling south into the Northern Hemisphere.
This event is unprecedented in November, as such disruptions of this magnitude are almost unheard of at this time of year.
The weakening of the polar vortex can trigger shifts in the jet stream, leading to cold, snowier weather in the Central U.S. and Eastern U.S. regions.

canonical_title: Indonesian Muslim group tells leader to resign over pro-Israel speaker

members.title: Indonesian Muslim group tells leader to resign over pro-Israel speaker
key_points: Nahdlatul Ulama (NU), the world’s largest Islamic organisation with about 100 million members, has called on its chairman, Yahya Cholil Staquf, to resign over inviting Peter Berkowitz, a pro-Israel scholar, to an internal training event in August 2025.

Peter Berkowitz, a former US State Department official, has publicly defended Israel’s actions in Gaza and criticized the idea of a Palestinian state, which has drawn criticism from Muslim-majority nations like Indonesia.

Indonesia, as the world’s largest Muslim-majority nation, has historically opposed Israeli actions in Gaza and advocates for a two-state solution, making the invitation of a pro-Israel figure a significant political and religious controversy.

canonical_title: Cold plunges and kombucha: Do winter wellness trends work?

members.title: Cold plunges and kombucha: Do winter wellness trends work?
key_points: Cold water swimming may produce a short-term physiological response, such as increased white blood cells, but this is due to the body's acute stress response, not immune enhancement.
The perceived benefits of cold water swimming are largely linked to reduced stress and social connection, not direct immune boosting.
Kombucha and fermented drinks lack strong scientific evidence to support claims of immune-boosting effects; the microbiome may change during infection, but returns to normal.

digest_abridged:
Winter wellness trends like cold plunges and kombucha show limited immune benefits; benefits may stem from stress reduction and social connection.

canonical_title: What we know about leaked US draft plan to end Russia's Ukraine war

members.title: What we know about leaked US draft plan to end Russia's Ukraine war
key_points: The draft US-Russia peace plan proposes the cession of Ukrainian territory in eastern Donbas to Russian de facto control, including cities like Slovyansk, Kramatorsk, and Druzhkivka.
Ukraine would be required to reduce its armed forces to 600,000 personnel, a move seen as a threat to its sovereignty and self-defense rights.

The plan includes a 'total and complete comprehensive non-aggression agreement' with 'robust security guarantees' for Ukraine, though these are vague and lack clarity on implementation or NATO-style Article Five protections.

canonical_title: The A.I. Boom Is Driving the Economy. What Happens if It Falters?

members.title: The A.I. Boom Is Driving the Economy. What Happens if It Falters?
key_points: The U.S. economy in 2025 is bifurcated: AI-related sectors are booming, while traditional industries face job losses, stagnant hiring, and declining consumer sentiment.
Investments in computer equipment and software accounted for over 90% of GDP growth in the first half of 2025, largely driven by AI development and data center expansion.

A.I. data centers are being constructed at a massive scale, with construction spending rising 35% year-over-year, and the construction industry seeing data centers as the primary driver of nonresidential spending.

canonical_title: The real reason behind China’s fury toward Japan’s Takaichi

members.title: The real reason behind China’s fury toward Japan’s Takaichi
key_points: Sanae Takaichi, Japan's new prime minister, has expressed military ambitions regarding Taiwan, suggesting Japan could respond with force if China attempts to take control of Taiwan by force.

China has responded with intensified nationalist rhetoric, economic pressure (e.g., restricting travel and seafood exports), and military saber-rattling, including a viral video titled 'Don’t be too cocky' that subtly targets Japan’s posture.
Beijing frames Japan's actions as a revival of militarism, drawing on historical grievances such as the Nanjing Massacre and Japan's colonial occupation of Taiwan during the 20th century.
